    Eminence of Nai Talim in Context of National Temperament

    Dr. Anil Kumar Roy     7 minute read    Read in Hindi   HOME    September 27, 2021   

    If India wants to be crown of education, wants to solve problem of unemployment, wants to increase production wants to develop villages and wants to establish supremacy of morality in the society, then there is only the option to adopt the concept of Nai Talim.

    Education is that system by which knowledge, understanding and critical ability develops. It seems at prima facie that this process benefits an individual. But as whole family also becomes part of the son’s success, wealth and prestige. In the same way society and country are also get deeply effected by the well education and cultured person. In this way education is not the matter of development of a person only, but in wider aspect, it is subject of national development and its identity also. This is why education is one of the main parts of the development policies of any country.

    One basic characteristic of education is very important, but ignored always. That is education fulfill the necessity of the society and the country in context of geo-cultural aspect. These necessities differ according to difference of geo-cultural aspect and also separates educational context and solution techniques. We cannot bring progress by providing overdose of vitamin B to the person who is suffering from lackness of vitamin C. Firstly we should be awaked by geo-cultural necessity, after that temperament of the targeted group and at last means and methods for solution should be considered. This process is important because in the way as any patient cannot be treated without knowing problem. Methods also have very important role. We can understand this through a historical example. During the period of dependence, many leaders and groups diagnosed the national and social need of independence. But the nature of Indian society could not be diagnosed by all leaders and groups. Therefore, the leaders and freedom fighter groups generally, who were active with hole and sole, adopted the way which was traditionally popular for opposition. There is no doubt that they were so much passionate for solving their national problem, but they failed to understand that the root and base on which the Indian society is standing is basically religious, cultural and non violence. Mahatma Gandhi understood this basic social nature of the country and he used it as a weapon against Britishers. And this was favorable for Indians. This was the reason for which Gandhi got enormous corroboration of society in the comparison of other prominent leaders for the same motto and the reason for this miracle was the recognization of the temperament of society and by adopting appropriate sources. Objective of discussing this irrelevant topic is that social psychology of necessity, temperament and means should not be neglected during discussion on education. Otherwise, after all sacrificing efforts desirous result cannot be gained.

    The education system, which is popular in India, is grafted plant of western culture. Its root lies in that society whose peculiarity is in individualism. Born from the root of mentality of individualism this system has its objective of prosperity of material resources. It is result of present education system that Indian society also facing towards materialism and individualism. It is not the inner nature of Indians. People here are always binding up through the lovely rope of familiarity, sociability and entirety. To feed others when himself hungry is the culture of Indians. Our basic nature pulls us towards sacrifice and entirety, but the presently popular education system push towards individualism, materialism and collection. It is why so-called higher educated society finds him in a variegated mental strain. But this strain is not felt by western people, though they are also nourished in same education system. Because this system tally with their traditional social nature, it produces favorable result according to their social culture. But, the same plant is unable to give sweet fruits in Indian culture. Education system interconnected with the culture can only easily produce well and acceptable result.

    We talked about selection of system. Now about process. Process of this bookish educational system is only information oriented. It does not have deep relation between knowledge and understanding. It’s only aimed for good marks through remembering chapters and it is the base of good success. Students can not create relation with chapters of their life, though they are well read. Their knowledge remains bookish only. Their lives become paralyzed, if they do not get any job based on their bookish knowledge. They cannot create their livelihood, because they have not any vocational ability. And the arrogance of bookish degree do not allow them to do so. Some days ago it was discussed in news papers that institutions like IITs are unable to product capable engineers with standard knowledge and creative ability. It is the situation that a student postgraduate with literature cannot compose a poem and a mechanical engineer call mechanic to repair motor of his house. These are the handicapped results of separation between work and knowledge. This is the result that education is not more than source of getting job of economically able persons and the mass do not feel attraction towards it. This education system, because not giving satisfactory production, is controversial from its beginning.

    Different from the current system, established by the Britishers during the period of dependence, Mahatma Gandhi gifted a vision of Nai Talim or Basic Education. It is the modern revised edition of Indian education system and tally with national temperament. As the warp and waft of national movement were weaved in view of temperament of Indian people, exact like this curriculum, process and methodology of Nai Talim were prepared in view of temperament of Indian people and need of reconstruction of the country. This educational vision has been prepared in view of our tradition, concordance and national necessity. If we like to peep into our tradition we shall find that independent and self dependent ‘gurukuls’ were in place of modern government financed schools. Pupils used to get undivided education of arms, agriculture, animal husbandry, morality, politics etc along with ‘granths’ (books). Knowledge of these subjects was not divided on basic level. That education was able to develop all the aspects of personality and also taught how to maintain or control social and national responsibilities. As a result, there was no unemployment and the society was under the sovereignty of moral values. When we had our own education system, our universities like Nalanda, Takshshila were most lightened educational hub of the world. But the Britishers, as destroyed our manufacturing system and trade spread in whole world, destroyed our education system also and established their own system for production for clerk. After independence also we kept enforcing strengthen that system in the dazzling effect of the western. We ignored our original system. Result of giving up own originality came in that form that in old age pupil used to come here for education, now we use to go abroad; there was trust of our products in the world market, now our market are full with foreign inferior goods. This example teaches that prosperity, development and regard can be found only to adopt our originality.

    Nai Talim is true and original education system for Indian society. It has essence of our culture and has been formulated according to our temperament. It is one of the 18 constructive programme of Gandhian concept for whole social-national development. Knowledge has been established in its full aspect to coordinate information with experience. Concept of skill development for each hand will abolish unemployment and unskillness among educated persons, which is one of the biggest national problems of western countries along with our country also. The whole country will be full with small home industries, when each hand will be skilled and then our national production will also increase unexpectedly. And we will not have to work as a servant for international companies, there will be independent entrepreneurs. Morality is the base of whole process in Nai Talim. In this way through the education of head, heart and hand, Nai Talim is the education system to fulfill all the necessities of the nation. This is why Gandhi himself has told it as a best gift to the nation – “I have given many things to India. But this system of education together with its technique is, I feel, the best of them. I do not think I will have anything better to offer to the country.”

    But it is here that the difference between the concept of skill development of Gandhi’s Nai Talim from the skill development being served in the name of new education policy today should also be properly understood. The concept of vocational courses in the New Education Policy is to learn any skill that can be earned. It has nothing to do with cognitive reaction. Thus, in the new education policy, skill development has been projected as an alternative to education and not related to cognitive education, the product of which will be an uneducated master of the educational process and thus defeats the noble purpose of education. But there is an interdependence of cognitive feedback in Gandhi’s work Learning while doing. This education not only strengthens the relationship of work with knowledge, but also establishes the concept of the aspect of applied pedagogy.

    If India wants to be crown of education, wants to solve problem of unemployment, wants to increase production wants to develop villages and wants to establish supremacy of morality in the society, then there is only the option to adopt the concept of Nai Talim.

    References:

    1. Constructive Programme: Its meaning and Place, M. K. Gandhi.
    2. Towards New Education, M. K. Gandhi, Edited by Bharatan Kumarappa.
    3. Baapu Katha, Haribhau Upadhyay.
    4. The Wardha Scheme of Education: An Exposition and Examination, Varkey, C.J.
    5. Bharat ka Itihas, Prof. Romila Thapar
    6. NEP 2020

    (This article was previously published in ‘Ailaan’ in section of special article.)
